Hospitalization Record.Chief Complaint: Ear discharge, hearing loss, and severe headache for 2 weeks

Present Illness.Onset: Onset occurred 2 weeks ago, patient presented with continuous ear discharge from the right ear, accompanied by progressive hearing loss, severe headache, and occasional dizziness. No known triggers.
Present Illness.Main Symptoms: Patients reporting persistent ear discharge from the right ear with a foul smell, moderate to severe hearing loss, and debilitating headaches. Symptoms have worsened over the last week.
Present Illness.Accompanying Symptoms: Occasional dizziness, tinnitus in the right ear, vomiting, and chills. High fever recorded in the recent days.
Present Illness.Diagnosis and Treatment History: Ear discharge culture revealed Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Initial antibiotics showed minimal response. No history of prior surgeries related to the ear.
Present Illness.General Condition Changes: Patient is febrile, sleeps poorly due to headache, poor appetite. Decreased mental alertness noted this morning.

Past History.Disease History: Recurrent middle ear infections during early childhood.
Past History.Infectious Disease History: Childhood illnesses including chickenpox, no significant infectious disease except for ear infections.
Past History.Immunization History: Up-to-date with vaccinations as per age.
Past History.Surgery and Trauma History: No prior surgical history. No significant trauma.
Past History.Allergy History: No known drug allergies. Allergic to dust mites.

Personal History.Living Habits: Watches television and plays video games. Balanced diet. Sleeps by 9 PM.
Personal History.Exposure History: No significant exposure to industrial toxins or radioactive substances.

Marital and Family History.Family History: Father suffers from seasonal allergies; mother is generally healthy. No history of ear-related diseases in the family.

Systematic Examination.Head and Organs: No visible deformities. Right ear shows erythema and discharge
Systematic Examination.Neck: Supple, no masses or gland enlargement
Systematic Examination.Chest: Thorax normal in shape and movement. Clear lung fields, normal heart sounds
Systematic Examination.Abdomen: Soft, non-tender. Liver and spleen not palpable
Systematic Examination.Nervous System: Alert, oriented. Cranial nerves intact, motor and sensory function normal

Hospitalization Record.Specialist Examination: Otoscopy reveals chronic otitis media with perforation of the tympanic membrane and purulent discharge.
Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination: CT scan shows soft tissue density within the right middle ear and mastoid air cells. Audiogram reveals moderate conductive hearing loss on the right side.
Hospitalization Record.Diagnostic Basis: Chronic ear discharge, hearing loss, severe headache, fever. Positive culture for Pseudomonas aeruginosa, CT findings.
Hospitalization Record.Differential Diagnosis: Chronic tympanitis - ruled out due to presence of mastoid involvement. Middle ear cancer - ruled out as CT did not show mass lesion. Tuberculous otitis media - lower suspicion due to culture findings.

Post-Admission Course Records.First Course Record: Patient admitted with chronic otitis media, severe headache, and febrile state. Diagnostic imaging and cultures support preliminary diagnosis. IV antibiotics initiated, ENT consult obtained for surgical intervention.
Post-Admission Course Records.Daily Course Records: Day 1: Continued IV antibiotics. Pain and fever monitored. ENT scheduled for surgery. Day 2: Symptoms persist but stable. Prepped for surgery.
Post-Admission Course Records.Senior Physician Rounds Records: Reviewed by Dr. H. Brown. Agreed on necessity of surgical intervention due to non-responsiveness to antibiotics and ongoing symptoms.
Post-Admission Course Records.Difficult Case Discussion Records: Discussed with ENT team. Consensus on surgical drainage and debridement due to chronicity and severe symptoms.
Post-Admission Course Records.Handover Records: Patient stable but symptomatic. Surgery scheduled. Antibiotics and supportive care ongoing.
Post-Admission Course Records.Stage Summary: Post-admission, patient prepped for surgery with partial response to intravenous antibiotics. Symptoms stable but persistent necessitating surgical intervention.
Post-Admission Course Records.Invasive Procedure Records: Not specified outside of planned surgical intervention.
Post-Admission Course Records.Consultation Records: ENT consult recorded for surgical intervention. Pediatric evaluation for baseline health.

Surgery Related.Preoperative Summary: Patient prepped. Recent history and imaging consistent with need for surgical drainage.
Surgery Related.Preoperative Discussion Records: Consultation confirmed need for tympanomastoidectomy. Risks include bleeding, further hearing loss, and facial nerve injury.
Surgery Related.Anesthesia Preoperative Visit Records: ASA Class I. Low risk for anesthesia-related complications.
Surgery Related.Anesthesia Records: General anesthesia administered. Patient tolerated procedure well.
Surgery Related.Surgery Records: Tympanomastoidectomy performed. Purulent material drained, and infected tissue debrided. Tympanic membrane repair initiated.
Surgery Related.Surgery Safety Checklist: Completed. All steps verified by surgical team.
Surgery Related.Postoperative First Course Record: Patient stable postoperatively. Monitored in recovery. Initial pain managed, no immediate complications.
Surgery Related.Anesthesia Postoperative Visit Records: No adverse reactions to anesthesia noted. Patient recovering as expected.

Post-Admission Course Records.Discharge Records: Planned after postoperative recovery and response to IV antibiotics.

Medical Orders.Long-term Orders: IV antibiotics (Ceftriaxone) 1g q12h, Pain management (Paracetamol) 500mg q6h PRN, ENT follow-up
Medical Orders.Temporary Orders: Blood culture if fever >38°C, Audiogram post-operative Day 5, CT head if symptoms worsen

Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination Reports: CT Head scan, Audiogram report, Culture and Sensitivity report
Hospitalization Record.Temperature Chart: Recorded febrile pattern with spikes up to 39°C pre-surgery. Postoperative normalization pending.
Hospitalization Record.Special Examination Consent: Signed consent for CT and audiogram.

Diseases of the Ear and Mastoid Process.Name: Chronic Otitis Media
Diseases of the Ear and Mastoid Process.Symptoms: Ear discharge, hearing loss, tinnitus, dizziness, vomiting, facial paralysis, severe headache, chills, high fever, etc.
Diseases of the Ear and Mastoid Process.Differential Diagnosis: Chronic tympanitis, middle ear cancer, tuberculous otitis media.
